text:

from hundreds of MIT courses,
visit MIT OpenCourseWare at ocw.mit.edu.

AMIT GANDHI: OK, so today's
topic is going to be biogas digesters.

So our objectives for the
class, or this session,

are going to be to learn
how biogas digesters work, when and where
they're appropriate,

some important design
considerations when you're building biogas digesters. And then we're going to build
a small-scale one in lab.

So you get to play
with some of the stuff.

Oops, I slipped slides. So these are some pictures
of biogas digesters. They've been around for a
couple hundred years, or maybe

150 years.  There are lots of different
forms for them, as you can see.

They scale up. They can be anywhere from large
industrial ones, like that one, or they can be smaller scale
ones for just a single farmer

or single family. And what is a biogas
digester is the question

that you may be asking. So a biogas digester
is something that takes organic
matter, normally animal,

human, vegetable waste, and
turns it into gas for cooking and also turns it into
fertilizer for crops.

So it's basically
taking organic matter and putting it
through a process,

and you get gas and
fertilizer from that. The process that breaks
down the organic matter

is anaerobic digestion. So you have bacteria, which
are found in the organic waste.

And when you put them under
anaerobic conditions, which means that they're
not exposed to oxygen, they break down all the organic
waste and form methane gas

and carbon dioxide.  And so you basically have
a giant chamber, I guess.

And in this chamber, you
have your waste here, with your bacteria in it.

And you let it sit for a while. It takes about
two weeks for them to start working once
you get them going.

And they break down the organic
matter in here and produce gas.

And you normally have
an inlet and an outlet. And what happens is, you
put in more organic matter

through the inlet, and it
pushes out some of the slurry or whatever's left over. And so you get
fertilizer from this end.

And the entire time you're
producing gas, which you can extract from there.

So about biogas, the
composition of biogas is mostly methane
and carbon dioxide.

So you have about 60% methane,
about 40% carbon dioxide. And then there are trace amounts
of nitrogen, hydrogen, hydrogen

sulfide, and oxygen.
And the amount

of energy you can
extract from biogas is 20 megajoules per cubic
meter, which is a fair bit.

Yes. AUDIENCE: How does
that 20 megajoules compare to, say, diesel or
traditional fossil fuel?

AMIT GANDHI: I'm not
exactly sure right now.

Yeah, I'll get back
to you on that. I had a chart with how
it compares to, like, how it could light things.

But I didn't put it
on here because-- yeah.

And so the parts of
the biogas digester are kind of like
what I drew here

but better, in this picture. You have a trench where you
put the biogas digester.

You have the biogas
digester bag, which is what contains
all of the manure and the slurry and the gas.

Then you have your
inlet and outlet. And you have a security valve. And you have a gas
reservoir as well.

So we're going to
talk a little bit now

about why you would
have a biogas digester. What are the advantages and
what are the disadvantages?

So now that you've learned
a little bit about it, we can brainstorm some ideas
about why you would use it

or where you would use it. Yeah. AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]
water and waste,

does that mean you add water to
it, or it's just whatever is-- AMIT GANDHI: You add water
to it to make a slurry.

So you mix manure and water,
and you get the slurry. And then you put
it into the system.

You guys will be doing
that later today, too. So I went to a farm and got
some fresh cow manure for you
to work with. So yeah.

Yeah. AUDIENCE: What are the
typical sizes of [INAUDIBLE]??

AMIT GANDHI: If you
want a ballpark size, I guess would be maybe
like 10 or 15 feet.

Does that seem right? 15-feet-long, maybe
like this size diameter.

Your trench would be kind
of like this corridor between the two tables. That's about the
size that you're

looking at for a
family, a household one.

But they can range from
small to large as well.

So if you look at
this, there's actually a lot of design that went into
the specific biogas digester.

And so we can look at the
individual components of it and figure out why, and try to
look through the design process

and thought process
that they used to come up with this design. Because this is actually
a pretty clever design for a biogas digester.

So does anyone notice
anything about this diagram

that seems like a cool--
like a good idea for them to have done?

AUDIENCE: Security valve? AMIT GANDHI: Yeah, the
security valve is important.

You don't want your
thing blowing up. AUDIENCE: Reservoir?

AMIT GANDHI: Yeah, reservoir is
also good because, with this-- because storing gas is
also somewhat of a problem.

And if you don't have a
place to store the gas and access it pretty easily,
then you're not going to have--
yeah.

Can you guys think
about the fence? I don't know if you
can see it in there,

but there's a fence around
this specific design. And the problem-- one of
the things with this design

is that the biogas
digester bag for this is a big plastic
bag that's covered

in tarp that's sewn together. And so you have this
giant plastic bag that's sitting outside.

And one of the cool
things about it is it's really cheap
because you don't have to build an external
construction for it.

But it's also-- like,
if you have cattle, which a lot of times you will
have for something like this,

and your Cow steps on this
bag, it's pretty much ruined. You're ruining your, like,
$300 biogas digester.

So that's why they
put a fence there.

Can you think of
other advantages

to having a bag, other than
just the fact that it's cheaper?

Yes. AUDIENCE: Is it somewhat
mobile, transportable? AMIT GANDHI: It's not
really transportable but--

AUDIENCE: Like, if you
had to move location and you bought a new house,
can you take it with you? AMIT GANDHI: Oh, you
can't really move--

well, I mean, it's
easier to transport to the site you're
installing to.

So you can make one
of these and, I guess, transport them to the location. I haven't actually
seen that done. I've seen most of them
being installed onsite

from the raw materials. But it's definitely easier
to get a large plastic bag than it is to get
all of the bricks you

would need to build a giant
biogas digester and seal it. Yeah.

AUDIENCE: Since you want to be
able to control the seal on it,

but since you have a bag, the
volume can actually change. Even though you say that
it doesn't create a vacuum,

is it-- AMIT GANDHI: Yeah. AUDIENCE: ----[INAUDIBLE]
the volume changing? AMIT GANDHI: So that's
actually a pretty cool thing

about this design
is your bag can get bigger and smaller,
depending on how much gas

is being produced. Because if you have a rigid
structure, kind of like--

OK. I'm just going to
redraw what I just had. So you have a box, and it's
say it's made out of bricks.

You somehow manage to
seal it from the inside so there's no air
loss or gas loss--
which isn't trivial, for one. But you managed to do that. And you put biogas in here.

And it's filling up. And it's producing methane, or
I guess it's producing biogas.

What happens as you produce more
and more gas in this design,

you start getting a pressure
buildup of gas in here. And if you're outputting it
into, say, a stove here--

if you are putting
it into a stove

there, depending on
what the pressure is of the biogas in
this chamber, you're going to get a fluctuation
in your stove temperature--

or your flame front, which is
kind of annoying and tricky to work with.

So if you have something
that expands, like a bag, it's better. You'll have more of
a constant pressure.

There are some
other designs that also try to regulate the volume
of the chamber for the gas.

There's one called
a floating dome one, which is actually
what you'll be making. And what it is, you
have a giant thing here.

You have your container,
which is solid, in this case. You have your slurry here.

And then you have
a dome like this that has your pipe coming out.

And what happens is this
can move up and down inside of your chamber. And so, as you produce
more methane gas--

or biogas, rather-- as
the pressure builds up,

it pushes up on the dome so
you're creating more of a space and regulating pressure with
the size of the chamber, which

is a pretty cool design. And the ones you guys
are going to be making are kind of similar to this.

But some of the adaptation
that are going to be-- you're going to take the
bottom of a Coke bottle.

It's kind of like that. And then you're going
to fill it with water.

And you're going to
have one biogas chamber. You're going to have
your chamber with slurry.

And then you're going to
have a valve coming into here and coming out of the water
and going up into that chamber.

So this will be able to move,
based on how much gas you

have in there. Can you guys think of
any other advantages to having this sort of
design, other than being

able to regulate
a constant amount?

So how would I know
how much biogas I'm going to have in this
chamber with this design?

I would have to put basically
a pressure valve on here

and read pressure, which is
kind of annoying and expensive.

And it's not it's not really
easy to get a pressure valve, in a lot of places.

But with a design like
this, if you let it float,

you can measure just the
height of this chamber because the higher the chamber,
the more volume of biogas

you have. So it's almost like
an indicator that tells you how much
you have as well, which is also pretty cool.

But I've talked a lot about
how biogas digesters work, in the design sense.

But we haven't really
got into why they're used or where they would
be applicable.

So let's think about what
are the advantages of biogas

to other alternative
cooking fuels? We can start by naming
other sources of fuel.

Someone want to throw
out other sources of fuel
that people use? So you have charcoal.
You have wood.

Anyone seen other
techniques that they use? AUDIENCE: Natural gas. AMIT GANDHI: Natural gas.

I've seen, in other
parts of the world, people actually just
burn manure straight.

I guess you also
have electricity.

AUDIENCE: Wait, biogas
comes from manure though. AMIT GANDHI: Yeah. AUDIENCE: Does biogas
mix with the fuel

or if manure is the fuel,
how does manure fuel without any processing?

AMIT GANDHI: In places, they
just take, like, cow dung and just burn it
as a fuel source. AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE].

AMIT GANDHI: Yeah, they
just take it and burn it. And then you cook
your food over it. AUDIENCE: Well, then, what
did the wood burning--

or how do they burn it with, or
how do they light it on fire? AUDIENCE: It gets dried out.

AMIT GANDHI: Yeah, you
let it sit out in the sun.

It dries out. It forms a briquette. And you can just
burn this briquette. And then it releases
energy when you burn it.

Yeah. AUDIENCE: It gives off
a lot of bad smoke.

AMIT GANDHI: Yeah. It gives off a lot of
bad smoke, bad smell too.

And the other thing
about burning manure directly is that it's kind
of taking a product that's

very rich in
resources, like there's a lot of organic
matter in there that could be used as fertilizer.

And instead of using these
good properties of that, you're just combusting it.

So it's a waste of
resources, basically, to burn manure directly.
What about wood and charcoal? What are disadvantages of that?

AUDIENCE: Besides where you're
using the D-Lab method of using

agricultural waste
to make charcoal, it leads to deforestation
[INAUDIBLE]..

AMIT GANDHI: OK. That's definitely a big concern. If you look at Haiti, so
much of Haiti is deforested.

And in places where you
don't have access to-- like, in a lot of parts of,
I guess, India and Nepal,

you'll have areas that are
heavily deforested already. And so they don't have access
to wood and charcoal even. And charcoal is expensive there.

And in places like that, where
people are farmers or cattle farmers, a technology like
biogas digesters makes sense.

Any other disadvantages
to wood, maybe?

Have you ever tried-- AUDIENCE: Collection. AMIT GANDHI: What? AUDIENCE: Collection,
time involved.

It's hard to keep
it good and dry.

AMIT GANDHI: Just as a
sense, have any of you been to developing world
places where you've seen people cook on three--

stone, wood fires, or
anything like that? What did you notice about
the cooking process?

AUDIENCE: It's
pretty inefficient. AMIT GANDHI: Do
want to tell people about how they cooked there?

AUDIENCE: Well, [INAUDIBLE]. It was my aunt's house. It was-- I mean, it's
just hard to come up--

it's just hard to get the fuel. So a lot of times
you just don't cook.

And they end up just
not being able to cook.

AMIT GANDHI: OK. When they did cook,
what was the process that they used for
cooking with the wood?

Because it varies,
depending on where you are. There's a lot of different ways
of combusting wood and using it in the stove.

What did that stove look like? AUDIENCE: I was a lot younger. This was maybe six years ago. So I think it was just
like buying the wood

and putting the
[INAUDIBLE] the wood. AMIT GANDHI: OK. You've-- AUDIENCE: Yeah, I'm not
sure what you're getting at.

AMIT GANDHI: Like-- [LAUGHTER] AUDIENCE: Sorry. AMIT GANDHI: Yeah, OK. Well-- AUDIENCE: It's just, like, hard
to regulate the temperature.

You have to keep feeding wood
to it to keep it burning. AMIT GANDHI: Yeah. And one of the biggest
problems with it

is also just the
smoke that it releases and the fumes from that,
which are both pretty bad.

Wood fires cause a
lot of pollution. And most people cook with wood
fires inside their houses.

And indoor air pollution
is a really big problem throughout the developing world. And so biogas has the advantage,
where it doesn't release

any of these toxic fumes. Yeah. AUDIENCE: Do people complain
about taste with the biogas?

I'm not saying that, like-- but I know several Colombian
people cook a lot on wood just for the taste.

They say it tastes better. So is that a drawback? That maybe it doesn't give
the same taste as wood,

as an open fire. AUDIENCE: Or is it even fire? AUDIENCE: Yeah, right,
[INAUDIBLE] or it could be bad [INAUDIBLE].

AMIT GANDHI: I
haven't seen-- have you seen that under concern? I think the way a lot of
people I've seen use--

how are you talking about
them using the wood? Are you talking about
them barbecuing something or grilling? AUDIENCE: No, so what
I remember, it was just

bringing the wood and
then those giant pots-- what are they called? And they cook, like, a soup
in there, or a chicken.

And even then, it's-- oh, it's wood-fire cooking. It's currently, you know, how my
mom used to make it, basically.

AMIT GANDHI: Yeah, I don't
have much experience with that. So, sorry, I can't help. Do you? AUDIENCE: I think it
is a behavioral change.

AUDIENCE: I think
a lot of it has to do with what techniques
do I bring with [INAUDIBLE].. Because with biogas, you
have to have gas stoves.

You have to have
that sort of thing. So I know that that's some
problem that they have.
[INAUDIBLE] differently. AMIT GANDHI: OK.

What about natural gas?  What are some of the problems
associated with natural gas?

Yes. AUDIENCE: It's expensive
and it's nonsustainable.

Unless It's produced
literally in your area, you have basically [INAUDIBLE].

AUDIENCE: You also need
the lines to connect to you if you're going to have--

AUDIENCE: So can it
be kind of dangerous?

AMIT GANDHI: I don't know. I don't think of it as
particularly dangerous.

It just-- you need a
lot of infrastructure to be able to provide
natural gas to people. And some places it's
available and not too bad.

When I was working in a favela
in Brazil over this IAP, they had a truck come
in with natural gas--

or LPG. And they would bring it
every couple of days, and at the same time, and
pick up old containers

and give people new containers
for a certain price. And that seemed
like it was great. But you can't really have that
same sort of infrastructure

in a more rural
place, for example.

Manure, we already talked about. And people don't really
cook with electricity

that much in the developing
world, that I've seen. So yeah, biogas has
a lot of advantages

to these other cooking methods. But it also requires
certain things.

You basically need a
lot of manure or waste to go into this biogas
digester every day.

I think the minimum
recommendations are having maybe two cows
or something like that,

or a few pigs. And if you don't meet
these conditions,

you're not going to be able
to have a biogas digester that produces that much fuel
for you to cook off of.

And the investment
for building one isn't paid back over a
reasonable period of time.

The other thing that's
cool about biogas is that when you pass your--

I think if you're not
using human waste, if you're using
manure, and you're using agricultural waste
or inorganic waste,

if you pass it through
the biogas digester at the end of it, you
get fertilizer, which is really good because you're
taking a waste product right

now, which is animal
waste, and it smells bad, and people try to dispose of
it in ways where they're not

utilizing any value from it. And you're getting
value from this product,

which is trash right now,
which is a really cool idea. Plus, when you pass the waste
through the biogas digester,

a lot of the harmful
bacteria get killed off in the process of producing. Or like, when it goes
into anaerobic conditions,

a lot of the harmful
bacteria get killed off. So what you're left
with is good fertilizer

that you can use
to grow crops with. And, yeah, so it's really
just taking a waste product

and getting value from there.  What are some of
the problems you

can see with biogas
digesters, based off of this cursory
introduction to them?

Yeah. AUDIENCE: You have
to [INAUDIBLE].. AMIT GANDHI: Yeah.

Well, I guess they
just cost about-- I think the cheapest ones I've
seen are around $300 to build.

But they're on the order
of hundreds of dollars. And so that's pretty expensive
to shell out at once,
to build one of these. Another big thing, again-- were you going to say something?

AUDIENCE: Oh, no, I was
going to say maintaining it and having to put
[INAUDIBLE] fertilizer.

AMIT GANDHI: Yeah. The maintenance costs
are pretty big as well. And the problem with this is
there's so many parts, as well,

that are very critical to
the functionality of it, that if one of them
breaks, you have to fix it.

Otherwise, your
entire thing stops. Like, if your bag gets a
hole in it, all of your gas is going to leak out.

So you have to carefully
design it and make it so that-- and you have to really
take care of this.

Because if you don't, then it's
just not going to work anymore.

There are some common sources
of problems that biogas

digesters have over time. And those are just leaks,
temperature, and pH.

So last year, we did
this lab in D-Lab Energy,

as well, where we
made biogas digesters. And none of them produced
any methane gas or biogas.

And it was because last
year, unlike this year, D-Lab was very, very cold. It was-- like, you needed
to wear jackets around,

or you just wouldn't be
able to walk around here. And biogas digesters
need a warm temperature.

I think around 50
degrees Celsius,

though that seems high now. No, that seems high. I'll get back to you
on the temperature.

But they have a pretty high
operational temperature. And if they're in that
range, then they work well.

And if they're not in that
range, they don't work well. So if you're in an area
that gets cold a lot or has huge temperature
shifts, then your bacteria

that are producing methane
under anaerobic conditions are going to die out
because of the cold.

And you might have
to come up with some of heating device for
your biogas digester,
to keep it warm. The last thing is pH.

For these bacteria
to survive, you need to have a pH
that's around 7.

So I think 6 to 8 is reasonable. And if your pH drops below
that or gets raised above that,

then you also have problems
with biogas digesters working.

just like for the
lecture-y part of this. So do you have any questions?

Yes. AUDIENCE: Are the
bacteria introduced, or are they [INAUDIBLE]? AMIT GANDHI: No,
they are found--

I mean, the bacteria that
are in the biogas digesters are the same bacteria that are
going to be in your stomach or cow stomachs.

Yeah, so they're
just introduced. Or not introduced, they're
just found in the manure. AUDIENCE: So for the
slurry that comes out,

can that be used
directly as fertilizer, or does it have to be composted? Because I know when
you use human waste,

you do have to compost it. AMIT GANDHI: So it needs
to be separated, at least.

Because there's sort of like the
liquid part and the hard part. Or there's the liquid part
and the solid matter part.

And a solid matter part
is generally composted, and the liquid part
is used as fertilizer.

Any other question? Yes? AUDIENCE: How do you
even collect cow manure?

Do they actually put a
diaper thing on a cow, or what do they do? I don't know, actually,
how that works.

AMIT GANDHI: I think they just
scoop it up afterwards, yeah. AUDIENCE: That seems
like less easy.

Horses are easier because of
the way that they're kept. But cows are usually
just kept in a field. It's obviously
harder to do that.

AMIT GANDHI: I think they're
usually tied up though. AUDIENCE: OK. AMIT GANDHI: Sometimes. AUDIENCE: I'm just curious.

AMIT GANDHI: Yeah, but you
don't put that diaper on a cow, generally. AUDIENCE: I don't think so. AMIT GANDHI: I don't think
I've ever seen that, actually.

But you just collect
it off the ground. AUDIENCE: Are there a lot of
the controls of the design of the biodigestive--

the valves-- you mentioned
that the security valve was really important. I'm sure there's a valve
right before the stove, right?

Where you can turn it on or off. AMIT GANDHI: Yeah. AUDIENCE: And so there must be-- that gas reservoir is,
like, the gas [INAUDIBLE]

of what you're not using. But there's pressure
built up there. So then, there's a pressure
buildup there, but there's--

I'm not sure what the
functions of the main valve and the security valve
and the gas reservoir are, and why, if those
two are in place,

it would be an issue
that the pressure would expand because it would just
go to the gas reservoir.

And the bag wouldn't need to
be able to expand anymore.

AMIT GANDHI: Yeah, so
that's a good question. I think there are other
designs of biogas digesters

that don't have all of these
security things, necessarily, built into them as well.

This is a design that
Victor presented. I don't if you know Victor. But he's one of the
D-Lab instructors.

And so this was one of the
designs that he presented.

And so I don't
know the specifics about the different valves. But I can find out for you
and get back to you next week.

AUDIENCE: Do you know what
the security valve does? AMIT GANDHI: Yeah,
it just regulates.

It makes it so that, if there's
too much of a buildup of gas, that the gas can
escape somewhere.

And you don't just
have pipes shooting off because of high pressure.

Does that make sense? AUDIENCE: I guess
I just also don't know what the main valve is. But [INAUDIBLE].

AMIT GANDHI: So you have
your security valve here.

So that chamber is
going to get bigger. OK, so you have your bag here.

Then you have your thing going
out to security valve here.

And then you have
your main valve here. And so when your
main valve is off,

this is sort of a closed system. And so no gas can
escape out of this.

Because you have-- this
is filled up to here.
I'm drawing this wrong.

So you'll normally have
your sewage level something like this.

And all your gas is
contained within this region

of your biogas
digester right now. And so if this valve
is off, and you keep producing
more and more gas,

your bag doesn't get
bigger and bigger. And at some point,
it's just going to explode because of
the excess methane gas.

And so what the
security valve does is it'll let out that
excess gas to prevent your system from breaking.

AUDIENCE: Is that
main valve the one that the person can
control, like, when they want to start cooking? Or is there another valve or
a switch, like that stove?

AMIT GANDHI: Generally,
there's a second switch at the stove end too. Right?

AUDIENCE: The security
valve is all passive. You don't have to
turn it on or off. AUDIENCE: Right, right, right. So then, what's
the main valve for?
Why would you turn it off? AMIT GANDHI: I'm not sure.

Yeah, I'm not sure about
the specific design. AUDIENCE: If your [INAUDIBLE]
is full, can you turn it off?

Be sure not to fill up your
gas [INAUDIBLE] turn it off [INAUDIBLE]

AUDIENCE: Or if you
had a fire [INAUDIBLE].. AUDIENCE: Does the security
valve go into the gas reservoir or out into the air?

AUDIENCE: Yeah, doesn't the
security just release gas into the atmosphere? AMIT GANDHI: Yeah.

AUDIENCE: So there's too
much going from one side to the other. It's just, [INAUDIBLE]. AMIT GANDHI: But
the other thing is,

you also don't want
to have a fully open-- like, one full closed system. Because if there's a spark
or something like that,

the entire thing is
just going to blow up. And you-- AUDIENCE: That would prevent
the reservoir from [INAUDIBLE]..

AUDIENCE: Is the gas
reservoir usually any [INAUDIBLE]
particular, or is it

just a space where you have
to be kept under pressure. I guess that's kind of
going with the "is there

a second valve?" AMIT GANDHI: I've seen lots
of different types of gas reservoirs.

I think the cheapest
one you can do is can just take another
second smaller bag and seal it. And then put an inlet
and an outlet on that.

And then this bag just
fills up and expands as-- like it-- yeah.

AUDIENCE: Can you compress
biogas and it will still-- do people do it in
developing countries?

Just building on your question,
do people compress it? And then do you have cylinders
of compressed biogas?

Is it possible to do that? Or that would be like, as
biogas, then [INAUDIBLE]??

AMIT GANDHI: I'm pretty sure
it is possible to do that, but it's a pretty
sophisticated process.

And I've never seen it done
in rural, developing world.

I've only seen it done
or heard of it being done on the industrial scale. AUDIENCE: I'm pretty sure it's
pretty hard to compress it.

AUDIENCE: Compress it? Yeah. AUDIENCE: Because there's so
many different kinds of gas that they start reacting--
